description:
Living arrangements

Explanatory notes for the following statistics:
12211 Microcensus

Definition:
The social relations between the members of a household are
used to classify a living arrangement. A living arrangement
may comprise one or several persons. Generally, the private
living arrangements of the population are recorded
statistically along two "axes" in the microcensus. The first
is parenthood and the second partnership. In accordance with
this pattern, the living arrangements of the population
include couples with never-married children and without
never-married children, lone parents with children, and
unattached persons without a partner and without
never-married children in their household. As it is a
household survey, the microcensus focuses on the network of
relations among the people surveyed within their own home,
that is, on their joint household. Therefore,
parent-child-relations across household boundaries and
partnerships where the partners live apart together are
disregarded. Living arrangements at the second residence and
the population in collective living quarters are not taken
into account.
